text: hi everyone 3:30 a.m. taro in the
morning shooting this right now here the

time for a review of the new Ice Age
record plowing into the field of love
you think it's the same field in here
same field maybe ice age is a Danish
post-punk and noise rock band that has
an incredibly dark and dismal sound they
flirt a little bit with goth rock - thus
far they have dropped - incredibly
abrasive crushing and depressing albums
albums that feature very chaotic
production and instrumentation very
drain and frustrated vocals from
frontman Elias bender Ronon felt their
sophomore LP is the more dynamic of the
two albums and their very short
discography I love the aggressive tracks
on this record but I came away impressed
the most by songs like morals a very sad
yet energetic very charged and dreary
piano ballad infused with Ice Ages
typically noisy guitars and drums in a
lot of ways the song was just ice age as
usual but with way more finesse plus the
promise the idea of there being more
instrumental accompaniment into the
future was pretty exciting it is
something that I in fact hoped for
I guess maybe even a little bit
predicted on their latest LP right here
their third full-length album plowing
into the field of love instrumentally
Ice Age went all out you've got their
usual just very heavy chaotic pummeling
punishing drums and guitars and vocals
but that is now enhanced by acoustic
guitars and pianos and horns and strings
there are more melodies woven into these
songs as well in general and the chord
progressions that Ice Age tends to favor
on this record feel a little more
harmonious even if that harmony may be a
bit of a minor one or a sour one and
even though I say just showing more
finesse on this record whether it be in
the way that they're writing these songs
because they are so
delivering longer songs on this record
that you routinely hit the four five
minute mark the entire album is longer
than any record they've ever put out
thus far reaching almost 50 minutes in
length considering their last two
records were under 30 minutes each it's
a pretty big jump but I say just showing
a lot of finesse as well in the way the
instrumentation comes together on this
record - ice age most definitely showing
a gentler side on this record a more
subtle side a more detailed side they
are writing more complex beautiful songs
however they still manage to maintain a
very gruff outward appearance they still
manage to write and deliver just
oppressively cacophonous songs Joy
Division and Bauhaus still seem to be
primary influences in Ice Ages music but
on this new record something I mentioned
on my track review for their song
forever
there is a huge Nick Cave and the Bad
Seeds vibe going on with this LP which
to me is a musical world that is not
untapped in today's modern music market
but I think under tapped similar to that
of some of the Bad Seeds best stuff in
the 80s and 90s Ice Age hit a balance of
beauty and ugly but even though this
influence may seem pretty apparent at
least to me I still think Ice Age has
remained its own animal even though they
have brought more instrumentation into
the fold and the drums and the guitars
they may be particularly noisy and
chaotic I think ice ages production
style has stayed roughly the same as it
was on their previous LP and the vocals
on Ice Ages record have have mostly
stayed the same as well though they have
become more dynamic and I think Elias
has done a better job of just sort of
exploring melody and exploring different
I guess inflections and stuff like that
all I'm trying to say is that he's not
really frightening or commanding in the
same way that Nick Cave is rather he
maintains a lot of the same emotional
characteristics that we know him for on
previous records the frustration just
the despair his singing is just the
epitome of emotional turmoil when he
sings it sounds like he is struggle
just crawling his way through a desert
he hasn't had a drink for days he is on
his last breath and their buzzards
circling overhead I was impressed with
the initial tracks that ice age dropped
before the release of this album they
really wanted to just send the signal
out there to fans that this record is
going to be different there's going to
be more instrumentation the songs are
going to be longer it's going to be
different expected to be different and I
mean loud and clear the message was I
expected a different record and this
certainly is a different record in the
best way possible in such a way that the
band is able to maintain everything you
loved about them in their previous stuff
but somehow have made it more complex
engaging compelling they just built it
up I think there's more variety on this
record than any Ice Age album so far
there are some wonderful slow burners on
this thing like the very dreary string
kissed against the moon which has some
wonderful piano arpeggios in it too or
even the song forever incredibly slow
song very dismal very depressing and an

so climactic especially with the horn I

thing it just feels like getting your
heart ripped out the chords are so heavy
they're so downtrodden the ending is
just really intense and noisy this track
makes the angst of even the saddest 90's

park the song Cimmerian shade is one of

all over this song and then there are
tracks on this record that I think are
outright fun like the song the Lord's
favor one of the lead singles from this

a rockabilly thing taking their
post-punk e noise rocky guitars and

still through his
some compelling melodies for this song

there are moments where this album just

it's just it's just so rife these track
these structures so rife with the

they've made me feel like less
emotionally by giving me more musically
I think this is a fantastic record I
